title: General Cleaning
description: General facility cleaning requirements including waste management, debris control, cleaning tool management, housekeeping standards, and prevention of cross-contamination during cleaning activities

mandatoryStatements: Spills must be cleaned up immediately upon occurrence
Spill response procedures must be documented
Spill kits must be available throughout facility
Personnel must be trained on spill response
Verification of complete cleanup must be performed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly review of spill response records, quarterly training verification for spill procedures
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Immediate response to all spills, documentation of spill incidents and cleanup actions

requirements.text: Are waste and garbage frequently removed from production and storage areas?
mandatoryStatements: Waste and garbage must be removed frequently from production and storage areas
Removal schedules must prevent waste accumulation
Waste containers must be adequately sized and distributed
Waste removal logs must be maintained
Corrective actions required when waste accumulates beyond acceptable limits
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly waste removal log review, monthly assessment of waste management adequacy
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily supervision of waste removal compliance, immediate removal if accumulation observed

requirements.text: Are floor drains and waste trap systems constructed and located so they can be easily cleaned, do they appear clean, free from odors, in good repair, and flow in a manner that prevents contamination (e.g., from high to low risk areas, from high risk directly to drain system)?
mandatoryStatements: Floor drains must be constructed to facilitate easy cleaning
Drains must be maintained clean, odor-free, and in good repair
Drainage flow must be from high-risk to low-risk areas or directly to drain system
Regular drain cleaning schedules must be established
Drain backups or odors must be addressed immediately
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly drain cleanliness inspection, quarterly drain flow assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual inspection for cleanliness and odors, immediate deep cleaning if issues identified

requirements.text: Do high level areas, including overhead pipes, ducts, conduit, etc., appear clean?
mandatoryStatements: Overhead areas including pipes, ducts, and conduit must be maintained clean
Regular cleaning schedules must address high-level areas
Dust and debris accumulation must be prevented
Designated equipment must be available for high-reach cleaning
Pest evidence in overhead areas must be documented and addressed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly overhead area inspection, quarterly deep cleaning of high-level structures
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual inspection of overhead areas, immediate cleaning if excessive dust or debris observed

requirements.text: Are plastic strip curtains maintained in good condition, kept clean and mounted so that the tips are not touching the floor?
mandatoryStatements: Plastic strip curtains must be maintained in good condition without tears or damage
Curtains must be kept clean and free from soil buildup
Curtain tips must not touch the floor to prevent contamination transfer
Regular cleaning schedule must be established
Damaged strips must be replaced promptly
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly strip curtain condition and cleanliness inspection, replacement of damaged strips
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual inspection, immediate cleaning or repair if deficiencies observed

requirements.text: Is personal protection equipment (PPE) for the sanitation crew in good condition and stored to prevent cross contamination to raw products, work in progress, ingredients, finished goods or packaging?
mandatoryStatements: Sanitation crew PPE must be maintained in good condition
PPE must be stored separately from production area PPE
Storage must prevent cross-contamination to products and materials
Color-coding or labeling should differentiate sanitation PPE
Regular inspection and replacement of worn PPE required
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly PPE condition inspection, quarterly storage area assessment for segregation
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly verification of proper PPE storage and condition, immediate repair or replacement as needed

requirements.text: Is cleaning equipment maintained clean and stored properly?
mandatoryStatements: Cleaning equipment must be maintained in clean condition
Equipment must be stored in designated areas preventing contamination
Storage must allow drainage and drying
Equipment must be stored elevated off floor
Regular cleaning of cleaning equipment must be performed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly cleaning equipment storage inspection, monthly equipment condition assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification that cleaning equipment is properly stored and clean after use

requirements.text: Is cleaning equipment identified in order to prevent potential cross-contamination issues (e.g., production, maintenance, outside, restroom equipment)?
mandatoryStatements: Cleaning equipment must be clearly identified or color-coded by use area
Separate equipment must be designated for production, restrooms, outside areas
Cross-use of equipment between incompatible areas is prohibited
Training must emphasize proper equipment selection
Regular audits must verify equipment designation compliance
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly audit of equipment identification and proper use, quarterly training verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily supervision of equipment selection and use, immediate correction of cross-contamination risks

requirements.text: Are all items used for sanitation appropriate for their designated purpose (e.g., no steel wool, metal bristles, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Sanitation items must be appropriate for their designated purpose
Steel wool and metal bristles prohibited on food contact surfaces
Only approved cleaning tools and materials may be used
Cleaning tool selection must prevent surface damage and contamination
Regular inventory must verify only approved items are available
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly audit of sanitation supplies and tools, verification no prohibited items present
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly inspection of cleaning tool inventory, immediate removal of inappropriate items

requirements.text: Are toilet facilities and hand washing stations clean?
mandatoryStatements: Toilet facilities must be maintained in clean and sanitary condition
Handwashing stations must be kept clean and functional
Regular cleaning schedules must be established and documented
Multiple daily cleanings required based on usage
Immediate cleaning if unsanitary conditions observed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily cleanliness inspection of all toilet facilities and handwashing stations, weekly deep cleaning verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Multiple daily checks and cleaning as needed, immediate response to sanitation issues

requirements.text: Are worker break facilities clean, including microwaves and refrigerators, and no rotting or out of date foodstuffs?
mandatoryStatements: Worker break facilities must be maintained clean and sanitary
Microwaves and refrigerators must be cleaned regularly
Rotting or expired food must be removed immediately
Cleaning schedules must include all break area equipment
Regular inspections must verify cleanliness and food disposal
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly break facility cleanliness inspection, monthly refrigerator and microwave deep cleaning
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily visual inspection, immediate removal of expired or spoiled food items

requirements.text: Is the maintenance shop organized, with equipment and spares stored in a neat and tidy fashion?
mandatoryStatements: Maintenance shop must be organized with designated storage locations
Equipment and spare parts must be stored in neat and orderly fashion
Inventory management system should be implemented
Regular shop organization and cleaning must occur
5S or similar organizational principles should be applied
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly maintenance shop organization inspection, quarterly inventory and organization assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly shop cleanliness and organization verification, continuous improvement of organization systems

requirements.text: Are internal transport vehicles (e.g., forklifts, bobcats, pallet jacks, carts, floor cleaners, etc.), clean, do not emit toxic fumes and are being used in a sanitary manner?
mandatoryStatements: Internal transport vehicles must be maintained clean and in good repair
Vehicles must not emit toxic fumes that could contaminate products
Electric or propane vehicles preferred over diesel in food areas
Vehicles must be operated in sanitary manner preventing product contamination
Regular vehicle cleaning and maintenance schedules required
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly vehicle cleanliness and condition inspection, quarterly emissions verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual inspection of vehicle cleanliness, immediate cleaning if contamination risk observed

requirements.text: Are shipping trucks clean and in good condition?
mandatoryStatements: Shipping trucks and trailers must be clean before loading
Pre-loading inspection must verify truck cleanliness and condition
Trucks must be free from odors, debris, and contamination
Temperature control equipment must be functional when required
Rejection criteria must be established for unacceptable truck conditions
requirements.verificationExpectations: Documented pre-loading inspection for every truck, monthly review of truck rejection records
requirements.monitoringExpectations: 100% pre-loading truck inspection, immediate rejection and cleaning or replacement of unsuitable trucks

capaInject: Implement immediate spill response protocols with designated spill kits located throughout the facility and trained personnel available at all times during operations.
Establish waste removal schedules with documented frequency requirements and corrective actions when waste accumulates beyond acceptable limits.
Create drain and waste trap cleaning procedures with scheduled deep cleaning, inspection protocols, and corrective actions for odors or backup situations.
Develop overhead area cleaning schedules using designated high-reach equipment and document findings of dust, debris, or pest evidence with corrective actions.
Implement PPE segregation and storage systems to prevent cross-contamination between sanitation, production, maintenance, and restroom areas with color-coding or labeling.
traceabilityInject: Maintain spill incident logs showing date, time, location, material spilled, quantity, cleanup actions taken, verification of complete cleanup, and person responsible.
Keep waste removal logs documenting dates, times, areas serviced, waste quantities, disposal destinations, and personnel performing removals.
Document drain cleaning activities showing dates cleaned, methods used, findings of blockages or damage, corrective actions taken, and verification of proper function.
Maintain high-level cleaning logs showing dates, areas cleaned, findings of accumulated dust or debris, corrective actions, and verification signatures.
Keep cleaning equipment usage logs tracking which equipment is used in which areas, cleaning schedules for equipment, findings of damage or contamination, and replacement dates.
micro_inject: Spills create immediate microbial growth opportunities as product residues provide nutrients for rapid bacterial multiplication; delays in cleanup allow pathogen establishment.
Accumulated waste and garbage serve as attractants for pests while providing harborage and breeding sites for flies, rodents, and other vectors that spread pathogens throughout facilities.
Dirty drains harbor biofilm communities including Listeria monocytogenes that persist despite routine sanitation; drain aerosols and splashing spread these pathogens to nearby surfaces.

Dust accumulation on overhead structures provides nutrients supporting bacterial and mold growth; gravity settling and air currents deposit these contaminants onto products and food contact surfaces below.

Cross-contaminated cleaning equipment transfers pathogens from high-risk areas (restrooms, drains, floors) to food contact surfaces; improper equipment storage allows bacterial growth on moist cleaning tools.
